subject: Ethics
title: Discrimination and Bias at Work
description: Learn Discrimination and Bias at Work in one minute.

hook.text: Identical resumes. One name: Emily. Other name: Lakisha. Emily got 50% more callbacks.

buildup.text: A landmark 2003 study proved what minorities already knew: names alone trigger hiring discrimination.

discovery.text: Workplace discrimination isn't always overt. Unconscious bias shapes who gets hired, promoted, and heard.

twist.text: Diversity training became a $8 billion industry, but meta-analyses show most programs have little lasting effect.

climax.text: Structural changesâ€”blind resume reviews, diverse hiring panelsâ€”work better than teaching people to 'not be biased.'

punchline.text: You can't train bias away. You can design it out.

quiz.question: What approach is most effective at reducing workplace discrimination?
options: Structural changes like blind resume reviews and diverse panels
Ignoring the issue and hoping it resolves itself
